organization.fullName: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

identificationModule.officialTitle: Randomized Trial of Enteral Vitamin D Supplementation in Infants < 28 Weeks Gestational Age or <1000 Grams Birth Weight

responsibleParty.investigatorAffiliation: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

leadSponsor.name: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

collaborators.name: National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences (NCATS)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The objective of the study is to compare supplementation with vitamin D at 800 IU/day to usual care for the first 28 days after birth with respect to 25 (OH) vitamin D levels and indicators of likely or plausible effects of vitamin D supplementation on the function or structure of the lung, bones, immune system, and brain in extremely premature (EP) infants who are \<28 weeks gestational age (GA) or \<1000 grams of birth weight (BW). The study results will be analyzed as intention to treat Bayesian analyses (Frequentist analyses will also be performed).

armGroups.label: Usual care plus placebo
armGroups.description: Infants will receive placebo (normal saline) in the first 28 days after birth. Care will be unaffected and provided based on the judgment of the attending neonatal faculty and NICU policies and routine practices. When the infant receives about 120 to 160 mL/kg/day of fortified milk at 24 kcal/ounce, the infant will receive supplementation with 400 IU/day of vitamin D as usual care.

armGroups.label: Usual care plus vitamin D supplementation
armGroups.description: Infants will receive cholecalciferol 800 IU/day in the first 28 days after birth, given enterally four times per day (0.5mL per dose = 200 IU) until the infant is provided 400 IU/day (when feedings reach about 120 -160 mL/kg/day). At that point the study cholecalciferol will be reduced to 400 IU/day for a total supplementation of 800 IU/day.
interventionNames: Dietary Supplement: 800 IU/day vitamin D supplementation with feedings in the first 28 days after birth

interventions.name: Placebo
interventions.description: Placebo is normal saline, given in the first 28 days after birth, prepared to have the same volume and appearance as vitamin D, which is a clear odorless solution.

interventions.name: 800 IU/day vitamin D supplementation with feedings in the first 28 days after birth
interventions.description: 800 IU/day Vitamin D supplementation until 400 IU/day are provided as part of usual care (started when infants receive full feedings of about 120-160 mL/kg/day). At that point the intervention becomes a supplement of 400 IU/day above that given with usual care. In this way all infants in the intervention group receive 800 IU/day of vitamin D total supplementation in the first 28 days after birth with feedings.
armGroupLabels: Usual care plus vitamin D supplementation

interventions.name: Usual Care
interventions.description: Care will be unaffected and provided based on the judgment of the attending neonatal faculty and NICU policies and routine practices. When the infant receives about 120 to 160 mL/kg/day of fortified milk at 24 kcal/ounce, the infant will receive supplementation with 400 IU/day of vitamin D as usual care.
armGroupLabels: Usual care plus vitamin D supplementation

secondaryOutcomes.measure: 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25[OH]D) level
Type of respiratory support required at 36 weeks postmenstrual age
secondaryOutcomes.description:
Data will be reported categorically as:

* Number of participants who survive without respiratory support
* Number of participants who survive with nasal cannula at ≤ 2 liters (L)/minute
* Number of participants who survive with nasal cannula \>2 L/minute or noninvasive positive airway pressure
* Number of participants who survive with invasive mechanical ventilation
* Number of participants who die
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 36 weeks postmenstrual age (or at the time of discharge home if earlier)

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Length of Hospital stay
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: from time of birth to time of discharge (about 0 to 60 weeks after birth)

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of participants who are still on respiratory support
secondaryOutcomes.description: Respiratory support includes supplemental oxygen and positive pressure ventilation.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of participants who receive steroid treatment to decrease respiratory support
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: from baseline to 36 weeks postmenstrual age

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of participants with neurodevelopmental impairment (NDI)

secondaryOutcomes.description: Morbidities include retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD), neurodevelopmental impairment (NDI), necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Infants born at \< 28 weeks gestational age (GA) or \<1000 grams birth weight (BW)
* Inborn
* Informed written consent in an Institutional Review Board (IRB)-approved manner

Exclusion Criteria:

* GA \>32 weeks regardless of birth weight (BW)
* Any major congenital anomaly
* A known congenital nonbacterial infection
* Prenatal diagnosis of disorders that affect vitamin D absorption (e.g, cystic fibrosis)
* Such severe illness or immaturity that the attending neonatologist judges intensive care to be unjustified.
